analyzed: anu sahagatam kāma rāga sayojana paṭigha sayojana anu sahagataḥ kāma rāga anusayo paṭigha anusayo tad ekaṭṭhā ca kilesā
translated: The fetters of sensual desire and repulsion, the underlying tendencies of sensual desire and repulsion, and the defilements associated with them.

analyzed: ayam tatiyā sīmā
translated: This is the third boundary.

original: Rūparāgo arūparāgo māno uddhaccaṁ avijjā, mānānusayo bhavarāgānusayo avijjānusayo, tadekaṭṭhā ca kilesā—
analyzed: rūpa rāgaḥ arūpa rāgaḥ mānaḥ uddhaccam avijjā māna anusayaḥ bhava rāga anusayaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ tad ekaṭṭhā ca kilesā
translated: Lust for form, lust for the formless, conceit, agitation, ignorance, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to lust for existence, the underlying tendency to ignorance, and the defilements associated with them.

analyzed: ayam catutthā sīmā
translated: This is the fourth boundary.

original: Yato ca catūhi ariyamaggehi imā catasso sīmāyo atikkanto hoti samatikkanto vītivatto, so vuccati sīmātigo.
analyzed: yatas ca catūhi ariya maggehi imāḥ catasso sīmāyaḥ atikkantaḥ hoti samatikkantaḥ vītivatto so vuccati sīmātigo
translated: And when someone has gone beyond, has gone over, has crossed over, has passed over these four boundaries by means of the four noble paths, he is called one who has gone beyond the boundaries.

analyzed: brāhmaṇo ti sattannam dhammānam bāhitattā brāhmaṇo
translated: A brahmin: because he has expelled seven things,

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhi bāhitā hoti, vicikicchā bāhitā hoti, sīlabbataparāmāso bāhito hoti …pe…
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhi bāhitā hoti vicikicchā bāhitā hoti sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ bāhitaḥ hoti pe
translated: His bodily view is expelled, his doubt is expelled, his spasmodic practice is expelled. …

analyzed: asitaḥ ta ādi pavuccate sa brahmā
translated: He is called a sage, a brahmin, a holy one.

analyzed: tassa ati arahataḥ khīṇāsavassa
translated: His: of the perfected one, the one whose effluents are ended.

original: Ñatvāti paracittañāṇena vā ñatvā pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇena vā ñatvā.
analyzed: ñatvā ti para citta ñāṇena vā ñatvā pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇena vā ñatvā
translated: Knowing: knowing by means of the knowledge of the awareness of others, or knowing by means of the knowledge of recollection of past lives.

original: Disvāti maṁsacakkhunā vā disvā dibbacakkhunā vā disvā.
analyzed: disvā ti masa cakkhunā vā disvā dibba cakkhunā vā disvā
translated: Seeing: seeing by means of the fleshly eye, or seeing by means of the divine eye.

original: Sīmātigo brāhmaṇo tassa natthi, ñatvā va disvā va samuggahītanti.
analyzed: sīmātigaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ tassa na atthi ñatvā va disvā va samuggahītanti
translated: There is no brahmin beyond the realm of the six sense fields.🔽Having known and seen, he has grasped it,

original: Tassa idaṁ paramaṁ aggaṁ seṭṭhaṁ visiṭṭhaṁ pāmokkhaṁ uttamaṁ pavaranti gahitaṁ parāmaṭṭhaṁ
analyzed: tassa idam paramam aggam seṭṭham visiṭṭham pāmokkham uttamam pavaranti gahitam parāmaṭṭha
translated: he has taken it as highest, as best, as foremost, as the chief, as the best of all.

original: abhiniviṭṭhaṁ ajjhositaṁ adhimuttaṁ natthi na santi na saṁvijjati nupalabbhati, pahīnaṁ
analyzed: abhiniviṭṭham ajjhositam adhimuttam natthi na santi na sa vijjati na upalabbhati pahīna
translated: There is no, there are none, there are not any, they do not exist, they are not found, they are abandoned,

original: samucchinnaṁ vūpasantaṁ paṭipassaddhaṁ abhabbuppattikaṁ ñāṇagginā daḍḍhanti—
analyzed: samucchinnam vūpasantam paṭipassaddham abhabbuppattikam ñāṇa agginā daḍḍhanti
translated: they are cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so that they are no more subject to future arising—destroyed by the fire of knowledge.

original: sīmātigo brāhmaṇo tassa natthi ñatvā va disvā va samuggahītaṁ.
analyzed: sīmātigaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ tassa na atthi ñatvā va disvā va
translated: There is no brahmin beyond the realm of the six sense fields. Having known and seen, he has grasped it.

analyzed: na rāga rāgī na virāga rattā uti
translated: He is neither attached to passion nor detached from passion.

original: Rāgarattā vuccanti ye pañcasu kāmaguṇesu rattā giddhā gadhitā mucchitā ajjhosannā laggā laggitā palibuddhā.
analyzed: rāga rattāḥ vuccanti ye pañcasu kāmaguṇesu rattā giddhā gadhitā mucchitā ajjhosannā laggā laggitā palibuddhā
translated: “Lustful for lust” : those who are lustful, greedy, infatuated, infatuated with, devoted to, attached, clinging, holding on to, the five strands of sense pleasure are called “lustful for lust.”

original: Virāgarattā vuccanti ye rūpāvacaraarūpāvacarasamāpattīsu rattā giddhā gadhitā mucchitā ajjhosannā laggā laggitā palibuddhā.
analyzed: virāga rattāḥ vuccanti ye rūpāvacara arūpāvacara samāpattīsu rattā giddhā gadhitā mucchitā ajjhosannā laggā laggitā palibuddhā
translated: “Lustful for dispassion” : those who are lustful, greedy, infatuated, infatuated with, devoted to, attached, clinging, holding on to, the attainments of the fine-material and immaterial spheres are called “lustful for dispassion.”

original: Na rāgarāgī na virāgarattoti yato kāmarāgo ca rūparāgo ca arūparāgo ca pahīnā honti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
analyzed: na rāga rāgī na virāga rattaḥ iti yatas kāma rāgaḥ ca rūpa rāgaḥ ca arūpa rāgaḥ ca pahīnāḥ honti ucchinna mūlā tālāvatthuka tā anabhāvaṅka tā āyatim an uppāda dhammā
translated: “Not lusting for lust, not lusting for dispassion” : when lust for sensual desires, lust for form, and lust for the formless have been abandoned, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so that they are no more subject to future arising.

analyzed: ettāvatā na rāga rāgī na virāga rattaḥ
translated: To this extent one is “not lusting for lust, not lusting for dispassion.”

analyzed: tassa idha na atthi param uggahītanti
translated: “He has no higher self to carry here” :

analyzed: tassa ati arahataḥ khīṇāsavassa  tassa idam paramam aggam seṭṭham visiṭṭham pāmokkham uttamam pavaranti gahitam parāmaṭṭha
translated: “He” : the Arahant whose cankers are destroyed.

translated: Cut off, stilled, calmed, quieted, and unable to arise again, it is burned up by the fire of knowledge.🔽There is nothing here that he has grasped at.🔽That is why the Buddha said:🔽“The brahmin has gone beyond the boundary,🔽Having seen and known, he has not grasped at anything.
